results.title: Call her sausage
results.creator_credit: Gus Meins, Hal Roach, Hal Roach Studios and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Ben proves to be the undoing when Billy opens a new deli. Ben and Billy do a variation of the famous “who’s on first” skit. A Taxi Boys’ comedy starring Billy Gilbert, Ben Blue, Lucile Browne, Billy Bletcher.

results.title: Call an ambulance
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A social studies film outlining the work of Civil Ambulance organisations in an Australian capital city. At all times the specially trained ambulance officers must be ready to answer accident and hospital calls in any part of the city. Ambulance men are seen working in co-operation with a Boy Scout group, in the discovery and rescue of an injured man in an isolated country area.

results.title: Calgary cowboy stampede
results.creator_credit: Castle Films and United World Films
results.brief_description: On the screen in close-up, and often in slow motion - the furious action of the world famous Calgary stampede - a spectacle to pin every viewer to their seat. Sun-fishing broncos, dare-devil cowboys, thundering chuckwagons - they are all here in this film of the annual extravaganza of the west. From the series: The Sport Parade.

results.title: Calder Hall: how a thermal reactor works
results.creator_credit: Ace Films and British Information Services
results.brief_description: Report to Geneva on the progress of Britain’s first nuclear power station, Calder Hall (close to Windscale Atomic Factory, Cumberland), July 1955. Describes the construction of the piles and the reactor. The film covers the various stages from the beginning of work on the preparation of the site in April 1953 to the summer of 1955 when the power station was three-quarters completed.

results.title: Calder Hall
results.brief_description: A report on Calder Hall, Britain’s first atomic power-station, as it was in July 1955. An engineer explains the layout of the two piles and the turbine house which will eventually produce electricity for a wide area.

results.title: Cake decorating with Robyn Hamilton. Pt. 2
results.brief_description: Robyn Hamilton continues with her demonstration on cake decorating techniques. This part is for the more advanced student on the art of lace, frilling, insertion, extension.

results.title: Cafe and Boxes
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Nottage and Sydney Dance Company
results.brief_description: Two dance films based on productions conceived and performed by the Sydney Dance Company. “A day in the life of a Darling cafe” is the theme of ‘Cafe’ (62mins. 1995), written and choreographed by dancers Paul Mercurio and Kim Walker. The production resembles a mix between a serious dance work and a satirical cabaret piece and is a behind-the-froth study of cafe society. Music by Brett Cabot and Colin Newham. ‘Boxes’ (60mins. 1985) was conceived by Iva Davies, Bob Kretschmer and Graeme Murphy as a dance work which was first performed by the Sydney Dance Company and the band ‘Icehouse’ at the Sydney Opera House on November 7, 1985.

results.title: C.P.R. a lifesaving skill
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cooper and Australian First Aid
results.brief_description: This instructional video produced by Australian First Aid shows us what to do in the event of an an unexpected cardiac arrest. The video demonstrates with eerie reality what happens in the absence of Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation (C.P.R.) knowledge and demonstrates the difference made to a life when C.P.R. is performed. Mouth to mouth and chest compression both help to supply a constant supply of oxygen to a patient. Without oxygen, the dies dies after 2-3 minutes. A scary thought, but necessary to understand when placed within an emergency where every minute is vital. Following the DRABC method, this video shows us how we can avert a fatal situation.

results.title: C.I.A.: the secret files
results.brief_description: This made for television documentary focuses on the covert operations of the CIA (Central Intelligence Agency) of the United States, using an array of interviews with former agents, recreations, and historical footage. Divided into six episodes, each segment focuses on a different aspect of the organisation’s history. “Berlin cowboys” Dissects the many undercover operations in circulation after WW2 in Berlin, when the Americans were determined to protect Western Europe from the spread of Communism from the East. In the 1950s, Berlin was the spy capital of the world, and CIA officers were in the front line, competing for information and trying to win the propaganda wars being fought with the Russians. Also addresses the building of the Berlin Wall. “Hi tech, low cunning” Advanced technology, such as cameras in spy planes, aided the CIA in the clandestine collecting of vital information. To gain invaluable information on Soviet missiles and weapons capacity, the CIA started using air balloons, which were easily shot down, but these were soon replaced by the U2 aeroplanes, which were superseded by satellites. “Hidden persuaders” Fearing that the powerful and popular Communist party would win, the CIA sought to undermine the Italian elections of the 1950s. Their methods included poster propaganda, circulating footage of Communists destroying Catholic churches and letters from Italian-Americans deriding Communism. The CIA was also seriously concerned about the Communist alignment of Indonesia’s President Sukarno; their methods to undermine him included circulating a ‘blue’ movie of him (or rather an actor who shared his likeness) making love to a white woman. “Phoenix rising” Using methods such as torture, kidnapping and assassination, the CIA sought to undermine the command structure of the Viet Cong during the Vietnam War. An incredibly brutal chapter in the organisation’s history. “Executive action” This episode concerns actions taken in Cuba, with the intention of removing Fidel Castro from power. Examines the fiasco which was the “Bay of Pigs”, the innumerable assassination attempts on Castro’s life, and various operations conducted with a view to undermine Castro’s power. These schemes included sabotage, and manipulation of the sugar market in the hope of ruining the Cuban economy. Also examines the capturing and execution of Che Guevera in Bolivia. Because Castro was linked to Chile’s democratically elected President Allende, the CIA sought to incite a coup, removing Allende from power by any means necessary. After Watergate and against the backdrop of the anti-war movement, the CIA was under scrutiny and consequently brought under Congressional control. “Moving targets” Final episode looks at the CIA activities in the 1980s and 1990s - Nicaragua, Iran, the Iran-Contra scandal and changes wrought within the CIA. Some scenes of torture and murder, particularly in the “Phoenix Rising” segment, may disturb.

results.title: Bylines
results.brief_description: A program that looks inside the Sydney Morning Herald and the staff who put the paper together. “Bylines” takes the audience from the early arrival of the Chief of Staff, through the daily drama of leaks, phone tappings and piracy on the high seas to the convoy of trucks heading into the night with the first edition.
